author: Ashley Armstrong
title: Mulberry's new creative director finally arrives
text:
Retail and Consumer Mulberry's new creative director finally arrives Long-awaited arrival of Johnny Coca as the British fashion house looks to put profit warnings out of fashion Spanish designer Johnny Coca joins from Céline Comments 
After more than two years since the departure of Mulberry's Emma Hill , the creator of the classic Alexa handbag, the British fashion house has a new creative director. 
Johnny Coca has finally started work at Mulberry, almost eight months after he was first announced to take over the feted role in November . 
The Seville-born designer has had roles at Bally and Louis Vuitton and is known for his expertise in leather goods, the major driver of Mulberry's sales. 
Ms Hill masterminded the best selling Alexa satchel which transformed Mulberry, but failed to repeat the success 
Mulberry's chief executive Thierry Andretta, who worked with Mr Coca at LVMH, has insisted that the business remains committed to its ready-to-wear clothing range, despite leather goods, such as handbags and purses, accounting for 90pc of group sales. 
Mr Coca will be in charge of Mulberry's design team on leather goods, shoes, accessories and ready-to-wear collections, as well as "all creative aspects of the brand's image", the company said. 
“I am so happy to finally start my journey at Mulberry and it is with great enthusiasm that I embrace my new role as creative director", Mr Coca said. Our new Creative Director Johnny Coca arrives today to start work with the #Mulberry teams. pic.twitter.com/9GVc6hh7b1 — Mulberry (@Mulberry_Editor) July 8, 2015 
"I am thrilled to share my vision with the creative teams in London but it is also crucial for me to spend as much time as possible at The Rookery and at The Willows, our factories in Somerset, as they are the heart of our brand, and craftsmanship is the soul of our products. It is truly an honour to work with the team to start a new chapter of the Mulberry story." 
The British luxury brand has reported a sales revival since making a move towards more affordable leather handbags to make its pricing more "democratic". Mulberry had suffered a string of profit warnings after an attempt by former chief executive Bruno Guillon to raise the prices of its designer wares backfired spectacularly. 
"It is such a pleasure to welcome one of the most talented designers in the industry to Mulberry and it will be exciting to watch the brand develop under Johnny’s creative leadership”, Mr Andretta said.
